message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient most likely has pheochromocytoma based on symptoms and positive urinary metanephrines and catechols. Propranolol is contraindicated as it can lead to unopposed alpha-adrenergic receptor stimulation and worsening hypertension. The other options, Phenoxybenzamine, Nitroprusside, and Labetalol are all used in the treatment of hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and urinary metanephrines and catechols suggest a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, which is characterized by sustained and intermittent hypertension. Propranolol, a beta-blocker, is contraindicated as a first-line therapy in this patient because it can cause unopposed alpha-receptor activation and severe hypertension. Phenoxybenzamine and alpha-blockers are preferred as initial therapy, while nitroprusside and labetalol can also be used as adjuncts.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, urinary metanephrines, and catechols suggest the patient has pheochromocytoma. Propranolol can cause unopposed alpha-adrenergic activity in patients with pheochromocytoma, leading to increased hypertension, and is therefore contraindicated as a first-line therapy. Phenoxybenzamine and Labetalol are first-line therapies for pheochromocytoma, while Nitroprusside can be used in hypertensive emergencies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and positive urinary metanephrines and catechols suggest pheochromocytoma, and the first-line therapy for this is alpha-blockers such as Phenoxybenzamine or Labetalol. Nitroprusside is used for hypertension emergencies, but it may cause worsening tachycardia in this type of situation. Propranolol is contraindicated because it can cause unopposed alpha-mediated vasoconstriction and further elevate blood pressure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and positive urinary metanephrines and catechols suggest pheochromocytoma, causing hypertension, headache and palpitation. Propranolol is contraindicated as it reduces beta-receptor activity and causes unopposed alpha-receptor activity and paradoxically increase hypertension. Phenoxybenzamine, nitroprusside and labetalol are all accepted treatments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high blood pressure and positive urinary metanephrines and catechols are suggestive of pheochromocytoma. Beta-blockers such as propranolol are contraindicated as a first-line therapy in this patient because they can cause unopposed alpha-mediated vasoconstriction and severe hypertension. Phenoxybenzamine and alpha/beta-blockers such as labetalol and nitroprusside are commonly used to manage pheochromocytoma-related hypertension.

Phenoxybenzamine, Nitroprusside, and Labetalol are all options for treating hypertension in patients with pheochromocytoma.

Phenoxybenzamine, nitroprusside, and labetalol are commonly used to treat pheochromocytoma.
